content:
Please execute the following task in my repository mcpmark-eval-zl/claude-code:

I need you to implement a comprehensive label documentation and organization workflow for the repository.

**Step 1: Create Label Documentation Issue**
Create a new issue with:
- Title containing: "Document label organization for better visual organization" and "label guide"
- Body must include:
  - A "## Problem" heading describing the need for better label documentation
  - A "## Proposed Solution" heading about creating a comprehensive label guide for different label categories
  - A "## Benefits" heading listing improved visual organization and easier issue triage
  - Keywords: "label documentation", "visual organization", "label guide", "organization"
- Labels: Initially add "enhancement" and "documentation" labels to the issue

**Step 2: Create Feature Branch**
Create a new branch called 'feat/label-color-guide' from main.

**Step 3: Create Label Documentation**
On the feature branch, create the file `docs/LABEL_COLORS.md` with:
- A "# Label Organization Guide" title
- A "## Label Categories" section with a table that MUST follow this exact format:
```markdown
| Label Name | Category | Description |
|------------|----------|-------------|
```
The table must include ALL existing labels in the repository. For each label:
- Group labels by category (e.g., issue-type, platform, area, status, performance)
- Include a description for each label

- A "## Usage Guidelines" section explaining when to use each label category

**Step 4: Apply ALL Labels to the Documentation Issue**
Update the issue you created in Step 1 by adding ALL existing labels from the repository. This serves as a visual demonstration of the label organization. The issue should have every single label that exists in the repository applied to it.

**Step 5: Create Pull Request**
Create a pull request from 'feat/label-color-guide' to 'main' with:
- Title containing: "Add label organization guide" and "visual organization"  
- Body must include:
  - A "## Summary" heading explaining the label organization documentation
  - A "## Changes" heading with a bullet list of what was added
  - "Fixes #[ISSUE_NUMBER]" pattern linking to your created issue
  - A "## Verification" section stating that all labels have been documented
  - Keywords: "label documentation", "organization guide", "visual improvement", "documentation"
- Labels: Add a reasonable subset of labels to the PR (at least 5-10 labels from different categories)

**Step 6: Document Changes in Issue**
Add a comment to the original issue with:
- Confirmation that the label documentation has been created
- Total count of labels documented
- Reference to the PR using "PR #[NUMBER]" pattern
- Keywords: "documentation created", "label guide complete", "organization complete"

Note: Based on your understanding, solve the task all at once by yourself, don't ask for my opinions on anything.

Without proper documentation, contributors may struggle to understand when and how to apply labels appropriately, leading to inconsistent labeling practices and reduced visual organization.\\n\\n## Proposed Solution\\n\\nCreate a comprehensive label guide that documents all existing labels and organizes them into clear categories. This will include:\\n\\n- A structured table showing all labels with their categories and descriptions\\n- Clear usage guidelines for each label category\\n- Visual organization that makes it easier to understand the labeling system\\n- Documentation that serves as a reference for contributors\\n\\nKeywords: label documentation, visual organization, label guide, organization\\n\\n## Benefits\\n\\n- **Improved visual organization**: Clear categorization makes it easier to visually scan and understand issues\\n- **Easier issue triage**: Contributors and maintainers can quickly identify relevant issues using consistent labeling\\n- **Better contributor onboarding**: New contributors will understand the labeling system through clear documentation\\n- **Consistent labeling practices**: Documented guidelines ensure labels are applied uniformly across the project\", \"labels\": [\"enhancement\", \"documentation\"]}", "include_output_fields": ["number", "title", "html_url"]}

|\\n|------------|----------|-------------|\\n| area:api | Area | Issues related to API functionality and interfaces |\\n| area:auth | Area | Issues related to authentication and authorization |\\n| area:core | Area | Issues related to core system functionality |\\n| area:ide | Area | Issues related to IDE integration and features |\\n| area:mcp | Area | Issues related to MCP (Model Context Protocol) functionality |\\n| area:model | Area | Issues related to AI model integration and behavior |\\n| area:packaging | Area | Issues related to packaging, distribution, and builds |\\n| Terminal User Interface |\\n| bug | Issue Type | Something isn't working as expected |\\n| documentation | Issue Type | Improvements or additions to documentation |\\n| duplicate | Issue Type | This issue or pull request already exists |\\n| enhancement | Issue Type | New feature or request for improvement |\\n| good first issue | Issue Type | Good for newcomers to the project |\\n| help wanted | Issue Type | Extra attention is needed from the community |\\n| invalid | Issue Type | This doesn't seem right or is not a valid issue |\\n| question | Issue Type | Further information is requested |\\n| wontfix | Issue Type | This will not be worked on |\\n| external | Status | Issues related to external dependencies or systems |\\n| has repro | Status | Issue has a reproducible test case or steps |\\n| memory | Performance | Issues related to memory usage |\\n| perf:memory | Performance | Specific performance issues related to memory optimization |\\n| platform:linux | Platform | Issues specific to Linux operating system |\\n| platform:macos | Platform | Issues specific to macOS operating system |\\n| platform:windows | Platform | Issues specific to Windows operating system |\\n\\n## Usage Guidelines\\n\\n### Area Labels\\n- Use area labels to categorize issues by the part of the codebase they affect\\n- Multiple area labels can be applied if an issue spans multiple areas\\n- These help developers quickly identify issues relevant to their expertise\\n\\n### Issue Type Labels\\n- Every issue should have exactly one issue type label\\n- `bug`: Use for functionality that doesn't work as intended\\n- `enhancement`: Use for new features or improvements to existing features\\n- `documentation`: Use for documentation-related tasks\\n- `question`: Use when seeking clarification or information\\n- `good first issue`: Mark issues that are suitable for new contributors\\n- `help wanted`: Indicate issues where community help is particularly welcome\\n\\n### Platform Labels\\n- Apply platform labels when issues are specific to certain operating systems\\n- Multiple platform labels can be used if the issue affects multiple platforms\\n- Omit platform labels for issues that affect all platforms equally\\n\\n### Performance Labels\\n- Use performance labels for issues related to speed, memory usage, or resource consumption\\n- `memory` and `perf:memory` can be used together for memory-specific performance issues\\n\\n### Status Labels\\n- `external`: Issues that depend on external factors or third-party changes\\n- `has repro`: Issues with clear reproduction steps or test cases\\n- `duplicate`: Mark duplicate issues and reference the original\\n- `invalid`: Issues that are not valid bug reports or feature requests\\n- `wontfix`: content.text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed all steps of the comprehensive label documentation and organization workflow. Let me summarize what was accomplished:

## Task Completed Successfully ✅

### Step 1: ✅ Created Label Documentation Issue
- **Issue #54** created with title "Document label organization for better visual organization - label guide"
- Included proper sections: Problem, Proposed Solution, Benefits
- Added keywords and initial labels (enhancement, documentation)

### Step 2: ✅ Created Feature Branch
- Created branch `feat/label-color-guide` from main branch
- Branch is ready for development work

### Step 3: ✅ Created Label Documentation
- Created `docs/LABEL_COLORS.md` on the feature branch
- Documented ALL 26 existing repository labels in a comprehensive table
- Organized labels into 5 categories:
  - **Area labels** (10): api, auth, core, ide, mcp, model, packaging, security, tools, tui
  - **Issue Type labels** (9): bug, documentation, duplicate, enhancement, good first issue, help wanted, invalid, question, wontfix  
  - **Platform labels** (3): linux, macos, windows
  - **Performance labels** (2): memory, perf:memory
  - **Status labels** (2): external, has repro
- Included detailed usage guidelines for each category

### Step 4: ✅ Applied ALL Labels to Documentation Issue
- Successfully applied all 26 existing labels to Issue #54
- This serves as a visual demonstration of the complete label organization system

### Step 5: ✅ Created Pull Request
- **PR #55** created: "Add label organization guide for visual organization"
- Includes proper sections: Summary, Changes, Fixes reference, Verification
- Added 8 representative labels from different categories to the PR
- Links to Issue #54 using "Fixes #54" pattern

### Step 6: ✅ Documented Changes in Issue
- Added comprehensive comment to Issue #54
- Confirmed total of 26 labels documented
- Referenced PR #55
- Used required keywords

The workflow is now complete with comprehensive label documentation that will improve visual organization, ease issue triage, and help contributors understand the labeling system. The issue serves as a live demonstration with all labels applied, while the PR contains the actual documentation ready for review and merging.
